member.name: T:UMapx.Analysis.Approximation
member.summary:
Defines the least squares approximation class.
This class is a solution to the problem of finding the function A (x) ≈ F (x), where F (x) is the original function. More information can be found on the website: http://simenergy.ru/math-analysis/digital-processing/85-ordinary_least_squares

member.name: M:UMapx.Analysis.Approximation.#ctor(System.Int32,UMapx.Analysis.ApproximationMethod)
member.summary: Initializes the least squares approximation class.

member.summary: Gets or sets the degree of the polynomial.

member.name: P:UMapx.Analysis.Approximation.MethodType
member.summary: Gets or sets the approximation method.

member.name: T:UMapx.Analysis.Differential
member.summary:
Defines a class that implements a solution to a differential equation.
This class is a solution to the Cauchy problem for the ordinary differential equation y' = F(x, y).

member.summary: Initializes a class that implements the solution of a differential equation.

member.summary: Gets or sets the differentiation method.

member.summary: Returns the value of a differential equation.
member.param: The delegate of a continuous function depending on two variables

member.summary: Returns the value of a differential equation.
member.param: The delegate of a continuous function depending on two variables

member.name: T:UMapx.Analysis.Nonlinear

This class is a solution to the problem of finding the root of a nonlinear equation of the form F(x) = 0.

member.name: T:UMapx.Analysis.Roots
member.summary:
Defines a class for solving equations using the spectral decomposition of a matrix.
More information can be found on the website: https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/roots.html

member.name: M:UMapx.Analysis.Roots.#ctor(System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a class of equations using the spectral decomposition of a matrix.

member.name: M:UMapx.Analysis.Roots.Compute(System.Single[])
member.summary: Returns a column vector corresponding to the numerical solution of the polynomial: p(1)*x^n + ... + p(n)*x + p(n+1) = 0.

member.name: M:UMapx.Analysis.Roots.Compute(UMapx.Core.Complex32[])
member.summary: Returns a column vector of polynomial coefficients: p(1)*x^n + ... + p(n)*x + p(n+1) = 0.

member.summary: Used to debug data such as matrices and vectors.

member.name: M:UMapx.Core.Debugger.Info(System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prints a simple reflection-based summary of an object's public properties and methods.
member.param: The target instance. (Note: parameter name is uppercase by design here; typically it's named obj.)
If true, include members inherited from base types; otherwise, only members declared on the object's exact type are included.
If true, include static members in addition to instance members; otherwise, include instance members only.
If true, print method signatures (method name + parameter types); otherwise, print method names only and collapse overloads by name.
member.remarks: This method writes to the console: 1) The runtime type of the object, 2) A comma-separated list of public property names, 3) A comma-separated list of public method names (or signatures). Special-name methods (property accessors, event add/remove, operators) and constructors are excluded.

member.name: M:UMapx.Core.Maths.Sieve(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Implements a sieve for finding prime numbers.
Recursive implementation of a memory-optimized segmented sieve of Eratosthenes. The operational complexity of the O(N* logN) algorithm.The memory complexity is O(Δ), where Δ = sqrt(N).

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Arnoldi
member.summary:
Defines Arnoldi transform.
This transformation is used to reduce the square matrix to the Hessenberg form. The matrix A is represented as the product of three matrices: A = Q * H * Q', where H is the upper Hessenberg triangular matrix, Q is the orthogonal matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnoldi_iteration

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Arnoldi.H
member.summary: Returns the upper triangular Hessenberg matrix.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Arnoldi.arnoldi(System.Single[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes Arnoldi transform for the input matrix.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Bidiagonal
member.summary:
Defines bidiagonal decomposition.
This is a representation of a matrix in the form A = U * B * V', where U and V are orthogonal matrices obtained using Householder transformations and B is a bidiagonal matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidiagonalization

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Bidiagonal.decompose(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Performs bidiagonal decomposition using Householder transformations.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Cholesky
member.summary:
Defines Cholesky decomposition.
This is a representation of a symmetric positive definite square matrix in the form of a product: A = L * L ', where L is a lower triangular matrix with strictly positive elements on the diagonal. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cholesky_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Cholesky.L
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular matrix L.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Cholesky.U
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular matrix U.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Cholesky.chol(System.Single[][])
member.summary: Computes Cholesky decomposition for the matrix A.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Diagonal
member.summary:
Defines diagonal decomposition.
This is a representation of the square matrix A as the product of two matrices: A = B * D, where B is the Square matrix and D is the diagonal matrix. This decomposition is used to highlight diagonal matrices in other decompositions (for example, LDU-, LDL-decompositions).

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Diagonal.D
member.summary: Gets the vector of diagonal elements.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD
member.summary:
Defines eigenvalue decomposition.
The eigenvalue decomposition is the representation of the square matrix A in the form of the product of three matrices A = V * D * inv (V), where V is the matrix of spectral vectors and D is the diagonal (generally complex) matrix of eigenvalues. The matrix A can also be represented as the product of three matrices: A = V * R * inv (V), where R is a real almost diagonal eigenvalue matrix. Not all matrices can be represented in this form, but only those that have a complete set of eigenvectors. Eigenvalue decomposition can be used to find the eigenvalues ​​and eigenvectors of the matrix, solve linear systems of equations, invert the matrix, find the determinant of the matrix, and calculate the analytic functions of the matrices. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigendecomposition_of_a_matrix

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.R
member.summary: Gets the real diagonal eigenvalue matrix.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.tred2
member.summary: Symmetric Householder reduction to tridiagonal form. This is derived from the Algol procedures tred2 by Bowdler, Martin, Reinsch, and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutine in EISPACK.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.tql2
member.summary: Symmetric tridiagonal QL algorithm. This is derived from the Algol procedures tql2, by Bowdler, Martin, Reinsch, and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutine in EISPACK.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.orthes
member.summary: Nonsymmetric reduction to Hessenberg form. This is derived from the Algol procedures orthes and ortran, by Martin and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutines in EISPACK.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.hqr2
member.summary: Nonsymmetric reduction from Hessenberg to real Schur form. This is derived from the Algol procedure hqr2, by Martin and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutine in EISPACK.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.EVD.cdiv(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Complex scalar division using a numerically stable branch (Smith’s method). Computes (xr + i·xi) / (yr + i·yi) and stores the real/imag parts in / .
member.remarks: Chooses the scaling branch by comparing |yr| and |yi| to avoid overflow/underflow. If both and are zero, the result follows IEEE-754 (Inf/NaN).

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD
member.summary:
Defines generalized eigenvalue decomposition.
It is the task of finding a vector of values of V such that the representation: A * V = B * V * D. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigendecomposition_of_a_matrix#Generalized_eigenvalue_problem

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.V
member.summary: Returns a matrix of values V.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.IsSingular
member.summary: Checks whether one of the matrices is singular or not.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.qzdecomp(System.Single[][],System.Single[][],System.Single,System.Single[][],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Performs the QZ reduction of matrices A and B.
member.param: Matrix A (will be overwritten by the quasi-triangular form S)
Matrix B (will be overwritten by the upper triangular form T)
Matrix that accumulates the right orthogonal transformations

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.qzhes(System.Int32,System.Single[][],System.Single[][],System.Boolean,System.Single[][])
member.summary: Adaptation of the original Fortran QZHES routine from EISPACK.
member.remarks:
This subroutine is the first step of the qz algorithm for solving generalized matrix eigenvalue problems, Siam J. Number. anal. 10, 241-256(1973) by Moler and Stewart.
This subroutine accepts a pair of real general matrices and reduces one of them to upper Hessenberg form and the other to upper triangular form using orthogonal transformations. it is usually followed by qzit, qzval and, possibly, qzvec.
For the full documentation, please check the original function.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.qzit(System.Int32,System.Single[][],System.Single[][],System.Single,System.Boolean,System.Single[][],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Adaptation of the original Fortran QZIT routine from EISPACK.
member.remarks:
This subroutine is the second step of the qz algorithm for solving generalized matrix eigenvalue problems, Siam J. Number. anal. 10, 241-256(1973) by Moler and Stewart, as modified in technical note nasa tn d-7305(1973) by ward.
This subroutine accepts a pair of real matrices, one of them in upper Hessenberg form and the other in upper triangular form. it reduces the Hessenberg matrix to quasi-triangular form using orthogonal transformations while maintaining the triangular form of the other matrix. it is usually preceded by qzhes and followed by qzval and, possibly, qzvec.
For the full documentation, please check the original function.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.qzval(System.Int32,System.Single[][],System.Single[][],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Boolean,System.Single[][])
member.summary: Adaptation of the original Fortran QZVAL routine from EISPACK.
member.remarks:
This subroutine is the third step of the qz algorithm for solving generalized matrix eigenvalue problems, Siam J. Number. anal. 10, 241-256(1973) by Moler and Stewart.
This subroutine accepts a pair of real matrices, one of them in quasi-triangular form and the other in upper triangular form. it reduces the quasi-triangular matrix further, so that any remaining 2-by-2 blocks correspond to pairs of complex Eigenvalues, and returns quantities whose ratios give the generalized eigenvalues. it is usually preceded by qzhes and qzit and may be followed by qzvec.
For the full documentation, please check the original function.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.qzvec(System.Int32,System.Single[][],System.Single[][],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[][])
member.summary: Adaptation of the original Fortran QZVEC routine from EISPACK.
member.remarks:
This subroutine is the optional fourth step of the qz algorithm for solving generalized matrix eigenvalue problems, Siam J. Number. anal. 10, 241-256(1973) by Moler and Stewart.
This subroutine accepts a pair of real matrices, one of them in quasi-triangular form (in which each 2-by-2 block corresponds to a pair of complex eigenvalues) and the other in upper triangular form. It computes the eigenvectors of the triangular problem and transforms the results back to the original coordinate system. it is usually preceded by qzhes, qzit, and qzval.
For the full documentation, please check the original function.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.Epsilon(System.Single)
member.summary: Estimates unit round-off in quantities of size x.
member.remarks: This is a port of the epslon function from EISPACK.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.GEVD.Sign(System.Single,System.Single)
member.remarks: This is a port of the sign transfer function from EISPACK, and is is equivalent to C++'s std::copysign function.
member.returns: If B > 0 then the result is ABS(A), else it is -ABS(A).

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.GramSchmidt
member.summary:
Defines the Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process.
In mathematics, in particular linear algebra and numerical analysis, the Gram-Schmidt process is a method of orthonormalizing a set of vectors in the space of internal works. This procedure is actively used for orthogonalization of bases. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gram%E2%80%93Schmidt_process

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Hessenberg
member.summary:
Defines decomposition with a cast to Hessenberg form.
This is a representation of a square matrix in the form of a product of three matrices: A = P * H * P', where H is the Hessenberg form and P is the unitary matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hessenberg_matrix

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Hessenberg.#ctor(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Initializes decomposition to a Hessenberg form.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Hessenberg.orthes(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Nonsymmetric reduction to Hessenberg form. This is derived from the Algol procedures orthes and ortran, by Martin and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutines in EISPACK.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Householder
member.summary:
Defines Householder transformation.
This is a linear transformation H (u) of the vector space V, which describes its mapping with respect to the hyperplane, which passes through the origin. It was proposed in 1958 by the American mathematician Elston Scott Householder. Widely used in linear algebra for QR decomposition of a matrix. In addition, the Householder transform is actively used for orthogonalization of bases; ultimately, the Householder matrix has the following properties: H = H', H' * H = I; det(H) = -1. In this class, two types of the Householder transform are implemented: reduction to a three-diagonal matrix and construction of the Householder matrix from a given vector. In the first case, the original square matrix is defined as: A = H * T * H '. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Householder_transformation

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Householder.hmatx(System.Single[])
member.summary: Builds a full Householder reflector matrix for the input vector.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Householder.tred2(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Symmetric Householder reduction to tridiagonal form. This is derived from the Algol procedures tred2 by Bowdler, Martin, Reinsch, and Wilkinson, Handbook for Auto. Comp., Vol.ii-Linear Algebra, and the corresponding Fortran subroutine in EISPACK.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Lanczos
member.summary:
Defines Lanczos transform.
This transformation is used to represent the symmetric matrix A as a product of three matrices: A = Q * T * Q', where T is a tridiagonal matrix, and Q is an orthogonal matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanczos_algorithm

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Lanczos.lanczos(System.Single[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This function uses the Lanczos algorithm with full re-orthogonalization to compute k x k symmetric tridiagonal matrix T that approximates mat up to rank k with respect to transformation Q. That is, A = Q * T * Q'.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.LDL
member.summary:
Defines LDL decomposition.
This is a representation of a symmetric positive definite square matrix in the form of a product of three matrices: A = L * D * L ', where L is a lower triangular matrix with strictly positive elements on the diagonal, and D is the diagonal matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cholesky_decomposition#LDL_decomposition_2

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.LDL.L
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular matrix L.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.LDL.U
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular matrix U.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.LDU
member.summary:
Defines LDU decomposition.
This is the representation of a square matrix A as the product of three matrices: A = L * D * U, where L is the lower triangular matrix, D is the diagonal matrix, and U is the upper triangular matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LU_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.LDU.D
member.summary: Gets the vector of diagonal elements.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.LQ
member.summary:
Defines LQ decomposition.
This is the representation of a matrix in the form of a product of two matrices: A = L * Q, where Q is a unitary (or orthogonal) matrix, and L is a lower triangular matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.LQ.L
member.summary: Returns the lower triangular matrix L.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.LU
member.summary:
Defines LU decomposition.
This is a representation of the square matrix A as the product of two matrices: A = L * U, where L is the lower triangular matrix, U is the upper triangular matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LU_decomposition

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.NMF
member.summary:
Defines non-negative matrix factorization.
This is a representation of a rectangular matrix A as the product of two matrices: A = W * H. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-negative_matrix_factorization

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.NMF.nnmf(System.Single[0:,0:],System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes non-negative matrix factorization for input matrix.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Polar
member.summary:
Defines polar decomposition.
This is a representation of a rectangular matrix A in the form of a product of two matrices: A = U * P, where U is a unitary matrix, P is a positive definite matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_decomposition

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Power
member.summary:
Defines power iteration.
More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_iteration

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Power.J
member.summary: Returns the diagonalized matrix of eigenvalues.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.QL
member.summary:
Defines the QL decomposition of a square matrix.
This is a representation of a matrix in the form of a product of two matrices: A = Q * L, where Q is a unitary (or orthogonal) matrix and L is a lower triangular matrix. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_decomposition

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.QL.#ctor(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Initializes the QL decomposition of a square matrix.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.QL.L
member.summary: Returns the lower triangular matrix L.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.QR
member.summary:
Defines QR decomposition.
This is a matrix representation in the form of a product of two matrices: A = Q * R, where Q is a unitary (or orthogonal) matrix, and R is an upper triangular matrix. QR decomposition is the basis of one of the search methods for eigenvectors and matrix numbers - the QR algorithm. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.QR.H
member.summary: Returns a matrix containing Householder reflection vectors.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.QR.R
member.summary: Returns the upper triangular matrix R.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.QR.qrdecomp(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Computes a QR decomposition for the matrix A.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.QZ
member.summary:
Defines QZ decomposition (generalized Schur decomposition).
This is a matrix representation for a pair of matrices A and B such that A = Q * S * Z' and B = Q * T * Z', where Q and Z are orthogonal and S and T are upper (quasi) triangular matrices. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QZ_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.QZ.S
member.summary: Gets the quasi upper triangular matrix S.

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.QZ.T
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular matrix T.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.RQ
member.summary:
Defines RQ decomposition.
This is a matrix representation in the form of a product of two matrices: A = R * Q, where Q is a unitary (or orthogonal) matrix, and R is an upper triangular matrix. RQ decomposition is one of the modifications of the QR algorithm. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.RQ.R
member.summary: Returns the lower triangular matrix R.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.Schur
member.summary:
Defines Schur decomposition.
This is a representation of a square matrix in the form of a product of three matrices: A = Q * T * Q', where Q is a unitary matrix and T is a quasi upper triangular matrix (Schur form). More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schur_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.Schur.T
member.summary: Gets the quasi upper triangular matrix T.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.Schur.hqr2
member.summary: Reduces Hessenberg form to real Schur form.

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.SVD
member.summary:
Defines singular value decomposition.
This is a representation of a rectangular matrix A in the form of the product of three matrices A = U * S * V', where U are left vectors, V are right vectors, and S are singular values. More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_value_decomposition

member.name: P:UMapx.Decomposition.SVD.P
member.summary:
Gets the pseudoinverse matrix.
NOT RECOMMENDED.

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.SVD.svdcmp(System.Single[0:,0:])
member.summary: Core SVD routine for real single-precision matrices. Performs Householder bidiagonalization followed by Golub–Kahan QR iterations to compute singular values and left/right singular vectors. Populates the private fields: Ur (left vectors), Vr (right vectors), and Sr (non-negative singular values).
member.param: Input matrix of size n×m. Assumes n ≥ m when called (the caller transposes beforehand if needed). The method works on an internal copy (jagged buffers)
member.remarks: Uses jagged arrays for speed. Columns of U and V are orthonormal. The number of QR sweeps is limited by the instance field .

member.name: M:UMapx.Decomposition.SVD.SwapColumns(System.Single[][],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Swaps two columns in a jagged matrix (float[rows][cols]). No operation is performed if equals .
member.param: Matrix represented as an array of row arrays (float[rows][cols])

member.name: T:UMapx.Decomposition.UDL
member.summary:
Defines UDL decomposition.
This is the representation of a symmetric square matrix as the product of three matrices: A = U * D * L, where U is the upper triangular matrix, D is the diagonal matrix, and L is the lower triangular matrix. This decomposition is a specific form of Cholesky decomposition.

member.name: T:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE
member.summary:
Defines the Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE). Operates in RGB by equalizing luminance (Rec.709) with bilinear interpolation between tile LUTs.
More information can be found on the website: https://uk.mathworks.com/help/visionhdl/ug/contrast-adaptive-histogram-equalization.html

member.name: P:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE.ClipLimit
member.summary: Contrast limit factor. Absolute clip is: clipLimit * (tileArea / Bins).

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE.MakeBreaks(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes tile breakpoints (inclusive/exclusive borders) along one axis, dividing pixels into nearly equal tiles. Remainder pixels are distributed by adding +1 to the first rem tiles. Example: size=10, tiles=3 → breaks: [0, 4, 7, 10].
member.param: Axis length in pixels (width or height).
Number of tiles along this axis (>= 1).
member.returns: Array of length tiles+1 with cumulative borders; segment i is [br[i], br[i+1]).

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE.MakeCenters(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Converts tile breakpoints to tile center coordinates on the pixel grid. Center is computed as the midpoint between inclusive pixel indices: mid([a, b)) ≈ (a + b - 1) / 2.
member.returns: Array of tile center positions (float) aligned to pixel coordinates.

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE.PrecomputeAxis(System.Int32,System.Single[])
member.summary: Precomputes, for each pixel position along an axis, the indices of the left/right neighboring tile centers and their interpolation weights. This is used for bilinear interpolation across tiles. Complexity: O(n), no per-pixel binary search required.
member.param: Axis length in pixels (width or height).
member.returns:
Tuple of:
i0[p] – index of left tile center for pixel p
i1[p] – index of right tile center for pixel p (i0 or i0+1)
w0[p] – weight for left center
w1[p] – weight for right center (1 - w0)

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.CLAHE.BuildTileLUT(System.Byte*,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Builds a CLAHE lookup table (LUT) for a single tile region: 1) computes luminance histogram (Rec.709) over the tile, 2) applies contrast limiting with excess redistribution, 3) converts clipped histogram to equalization LUT via CDF normalization.
member.param: Pointer to the first byte of the bitmap data.
Stride in bytes of the bitmap row (may be > width*4).
Inclusive left bound of the tile.
Exclusive right bound of the tile.
Inclusive top bound of the tile.
Exclusive bottom bound of the tile.
Relative clip limit factor. Absolute limit per bin is clip = clipLimitFactor * (tileArea / Bins). Use 0 to disable clipping.
member.returns: Byte LUT of length 256 mapping input luminance → equalized luminance.

member.name: T:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur
member.summary:
Defines the Gaussian blur filter.
This is a very fast pseudo-Gaussian blur filter via N separable box filters (default 3).

member.name: P:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter size.

member.name: P:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.Sigma
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter size (>0).

member.name: P:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.Boxes
member.summary: Gets or sets a number of boxes (>0).

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.BoxBlurN(System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Apply N separable box-filter passes in-place. For each pass i: - run a horizontal box blur with radius radsX[i] into . - run a vertical box blur with radius radsY[i] from back into . If a radius on a pass is 0, the source buffer is simply copied through for that direction. The final result remains in .
member.param: Working buffer (and final destination) of size w*h.
Temporary buffer of size w*h (reused across passes).
Per-pass horizontal radii (length >= number of passes).
Per-pass vertical radii (length >= number of passes).

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.BoxBlurH(System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: One horizontal box blur pass with edge clamping (replicate). Uses a sliding window (running sum) to achieve O(w) per row.

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.BoxBlurV(System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: One vertical box blur pass with edge clamping (replicate). Uses a sliding window (running sum) to achieve O(h) per column.

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.ExtractToFloats(System.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapData,System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[])
member.summary: Read 32bpp ARGB bitmap data into 4 float channel planes (BGRA order). Channels are stored as [0..255] floats, no normalization or gamma applied.

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.WriteBack(System.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapData,System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[],System.Single[])
member.summary: Write 4 float channel planes (BGRA order) back to a 32bpp ARGB bitmap. Values are clamped to [0,255] and rounded to nearest (0.5 up). No gamma correction is applied.

member.name: M:UMapx.Imaging.GaussianBlur.BoxesForGauss(System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute odd box sizes whose convolution approximates a Gaussian with standard deviation . Returns an array of sizes where the first m entries are the lower odd width (wl), and the rest are the higher odd width (wu = wl + 2). This is the classic "fast almost-Gaussian" 3-box generalization.
member.returns: Array of odd box widths of length .

member.name: T:UMapx.Imaging.Operation
member.summary:
Defines the linear operation filter.
This filter works UMapxing to the following algorithm: C (x, y) = a * A (x, y) + b * B (x, y), where A, B are the original images, a, b are the coefficients.

member.name: T:UMapx.Imaging.ShadowsHighlightsCorrection
member.summary:
Defines the shadows and lights correction filter.
Shadow-Highlights correction is used to correct unevenly lit images. Unlike other local algorithms (for example, Single Scale Retinex, Homomorphic Enhancement, Flat-Field Correction) filter allows you to adjust the brightness values separately in dark and bright areas Images.

member.name: T:UMapx.Response.FIR
member.summary:
Defines a filter with a finite impulse response.
A filter with a finite impulse response (transverse filter, FIR filter or FIR filter) is one of the types of linear digital filters, a characteristic feature of which is the limited time of its impulse response (from some point in time it becomes exactly equal to zero). Such a filter is also called non-recursive due to the lack of feedback. The denominator of the transfer function of such a filter is a certain constant.

member.name: M:UMapx.Response.FIR.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a filter with a finite impulse response.

member.summary: Initializes a filter with a finite impulse response.

member.summary: Gets or sets the array of signal coefficients.

member.summary: Returns an array of filter response values when a discrete function is supplied.
member.returns: Discrete function in a Cartesian coordinate system

member.summary: Returns the frequency response of the filter.
member.returns: Discrete function in a Cartesian coordinate system

member.summary: Returns the phase-frequency response of a filter.
member.returns: Discrete function in a Cartesian coordinate system

member.summary: Returns the amplitude value at the given frequency.

member.summary: Returns the phase value at the given frequency.

member.summary: Gets the finished low pass filter.

member.name: T:UMapx.Response.IIR
member.summary:
Defines a filter with an infinite impulse response.
Filter with infinite impulse response (recursive filter, IIR filter or IIR filter) - a linear electronic filter, using one or more of its outputs as an input, i.e. forms a feedback. The main property of such filters is that their impulse response is of infinite length in the time domain, and the transfer function has a fractional rational look.

member.name: T:UMapx.Video.IVideoDepthSource
member.summary: Extension interface for handling Intel RealSense depth events.

member.name: T:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource
member.remarks: The interface describes common methods for different type of video sources.

remarks.para: This event is used to notify clients about new available video frame.

para.note: Since video source may have multiple clients, each client is responsible for making a copy (cloning) of the passed video frame, but video source is responsible for disposing its own original copy after notifying of clients.

member.name: E:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.VideoSourceError
member.remarks: This event is used to notify clients about any type of errors occurred in video source object, for example internal exceptions.

remarks.para: This event is used to notify clients that the video playing has finished.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.Source
member.remarks: The meaning of the property depends on particular video source. Depending on video source it may be a file name, URL or any other string describing the video source.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.FramesReceived
member.remarks: Number of frames the video source provided from the moment of the last access to the property.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.BytesReceived
member.remarks: Number of bytes the video source provided from the moment of the last access to the property.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.IsRunning
member.remarks: Current state of video source object - running or not.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.Start
member.remarks: Starts video source and return execution to caller. Video source object creates background thread and notifies about new frames with the help of event.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.SignalToStop
member.summary: Signal video source to stop its work.
member.remarks: Signals video source to stop its background thread, stop to provide new frames and free resources.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.WaitForStop
member.summary: Wait for video source has stopped.
member.remarks: Waits for video source stopping after it was signalled to stop using method.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.IVideoSource.Stop
member.remarks: Stops video source aborting its thread.

remarks.para: The video source constantly downloads JPEG files from the specified URL.
Sample usage:

para.note: Some cameras produce HTTP header, which does not conform strictly to standard, what leads to .NET exception. To avoid this exception the useUnsafeHeaderParsing configuration option of httpWebRequest should be set, what may be done using application configuration file.

remarks.para: Notifies clients about new available frame from video source.

para.note: Since video source may have multiple clients, each client is responsible for making a copy (cloning) of the passed video frame, because the video source disposes its own original copy after notifying of clients.

member.name: E:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.VideoSourceError
member.remarks: This event is used to notify clients about any type of errors occurred in video source object, for example internal exceptions.

remarks.para: This event is used to notify clients that the video playing has finished.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.SeparateConnectionGroup
member.summary: Use or not separate connection group.
member.remarks: The property indicates to open web request in separate connection group.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.PreventCaching
member.remarks: If the property is set to true, then a fake random parameter will be added to URL to prevent caching. It's required for clients, who are behind proxy server.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.FrameInterval
member.remarks: The property sets the interval in milliseconds between frames. If the property is set to 100, then the desired frame rate will be 10 frames per second. Default value is 0 - get new frames as fast as possible.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.Source
member.remarks: URL, which provides JPEG files.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.Login
member.remarks: Login required to access video source.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.Password
member.remarks: Password required to access video source.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.Proxy
member.summary: Gets or sets proxy information for the request.

remarks.para: The local computer or application config file may specify that a default proxy to be used. If the Proxy property is specified, then the proxy settings from the Proxy property overridea the local computer or application config file and the instance will use the proxy settings specified. If no proxy is specified in a config file and the Proxy property is unspecified, the request uses the proxy settings inherited from Internet Explorer on the local computer. If there are no proxy settings in Internet Explorer, the request is sent directly to the server.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.FramesReceived
member.remarks: Number of frames the video source provided from the moment of the last access to the property.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.BytesReceived
member.remarks: Number of bytes the video source provided from the moment of the last access to the property.

remarks.para: The property sets timeout value in milliseconds for web requests.
Default value is set 10000 milliseconds.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.IsRunning
member.remarks: Current state of video source object - running or not.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.ForceBasicAuthentication
member.summary: Force using of basic authentication when connecting to the video source.

remarks.para: For some IP cameras (TrendNET IP cameras, for example) using standard .NET's authentication via credentials does not seem to be working (seems like camera does not request for authentication, but expects corresponding headers to be present on connection request). So this property allows to force basic authentication by adding required HTTP headers when request is sent.
Default value is set to .

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.Start
member.remarks: Starts video source and return execution to caller. Video source object creates background thread and notifies about new frames with the help of event.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.SignalToStop
member.summary: Signal video source to stop its work.
member.remarks: Signals video source to stop its background thread, stop to provide new frames and free resources.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.JPEGStream.WaitForStop
member.summary: Wait for video source has stopped.
member.remarks: Waits for source stopping after it was signalled to stop using method.

remarks.para: Stops video source aborting its thread.

para.note: Since the method aborts background thread, its usage is highly not preferred and should be done only if there are no other options. The correct way of stopping camera is signaling it stop and then waiting for background thread's completion.

remarks.para: The video source downloads JPEG images from the specified URL, which represents MJPEG stream.
Sample usage:

para.note: Some cameras produce HTTP header, which does not conform strictly to standard, what leads to .NET exception. To avoid this exception the useUnsafeHeaderParsing configuration option of httpWebRequest should be set, what may be done using application configuration file.

remarks.para: Notifies clients about new available frame from video source.

para.note: Since video source may have multiple clients, each client is responsible for making a copy (cloning) of the passed video frame, because the video source disposes its own original copy after notifying of clients.

member.name: E:UMapx.Video.MJPEGStream.VideoSourceError

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.MJPEGStream.HttpUserAgent
member.summary: User agent to specify in HTTP request header.

remarks.para: Some IP cameras check what is the requesting user agent and depending on it they provide video in different formats or do not provide it at all. The property sets the value of user agent string, which is sent to camera in request header.
Default value is set to "Mozilla/5.0". If the value is set to , the user agent string is not sent in request header.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.MJPEGStream.Start
member.remarks: Starts video source and return execution to caller. Video source object creates background thread and notifies about new frames with the help of event.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.MJPEGStream.SignalToStop
member.summary: Signal video source to stop its work.
member.remarks: Signals video source to stop its background thread, stop to provide new frames and free resources.

member.name: M:UMapx.Video.MJPEGStream.WaitForStop
member.summary: Wait for video source has stopped.
member.remarks: Waits for source stopping after it was signalled to stop using method.

remarks.para: Stops video source aborting its thread.

para.note: Since the method aborts background thread, its usage is highly not preferred and should be done only if there are no other options. The correct way of stopping camera is signaling it stop and then waiting for background thread's completion.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: When video source class fire the event, they need to specify reason of finishing video playing. For example, it may be end of stream reached.

member.name: F:UMapx.Video.ReasonToFinishPlaying.EndOfStreamReached
member.summary: Video playing has finished because it end was reached.

member.name: F:UMapx.Video.ReasonToFinishPlaying.StoppedByUser
member.summary: Video playing has finished because it was stopped by user.

member.name: F:UMapx.Video.ReasonToFinishPlaying.DeviceLost
member.summary: Video playing has finished because the device was lost (unplugged).

member.name: F:UMapx.Video.ReasonToFinishPlaying.VideoSourceError
member.summary: Video playing has finished because of some error happened the video source (camera, stream, file, etc.). A error reporting event usually is fired to provide error information.

remarks.para: The video source constantly captures the desktop screen.
Sample usage:
Notifies clients about new available frame from video source.

para.note: Since video source may have multiple clients, each client is responsible for making a copy (cloning) of the passed video frame, because the video source disposes its own original copy after notifying of clients.

member.name: E:UMapx.Video.ScreenCaptureStream.VideoSourceError
member.remarks: This event is used to notify clients about any type of errors occurred in video source object, for example internal exceptions.

remarks.para: This event is used to notify clients that the video playing has finished.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.ScreenCaptureStream.Region
member.summary: Gets or sets the screen capture region.

remarks.para: This property specifies which region (rectangle) of the screen to capture. It may cover multiple displays if those are available in the system.

para.note: The property must be set before starting video source to have any effect.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.ScreenCaptureStream.FrameInterval
member.summary: Time interval between making screen shots, ms.

remarks.para: The property specifies time interval in milliseconds between consequent screen captures. Expected frame rate of the stream should be approximately 1000/FrameInteval.
If the property is set to 0, then the stream will capture screen as fast as the system allows.
Default value is set to 100.

member.name: P:UMapx.Video.ScreenCaptureStream.FramesReceived
member.remarks: Number of frames the video source provided from the moment of the last access to the property.

para.note: The property is not implemented for this video source and always returns 0.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.Point2X(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Maps a horizontal pixel coordinate to the corresponding data-space X value.
member.param: Pixel position along X (0 at the left edge, increasing to the right).
Data-space minimum (left bound) of the X axis
Data-space maximum (right bound) of the X axis
Total drawable width in pixels (must be > 0)
member.returns: The data-space value X that corresponds to pixel .
member.remarks: Assumes a linear mapping from pixel space [0, ] to data space [, ].

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.Point2Y(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Maps a vertical pixel coordinate to the corresponding data-space Y value.
member.param: Pixel position along Y (0 at the top edge, increasing downward — screen coordinates).
Data-space minimum (bottom bound) of the Y axis
Data-space maximum (top bound) of the Y axis
Total drawable height in pixels (must be > 0)
member.returns: The data-space value Y that corresponds to pixel .
member.remarks: Uses an inverted Y axis (top-left origin), common for raster graphics: pixel 0 maps to , pixel maps to .

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.X2Point(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Maps a data-space X value to the corresponding horizontal pixel coordinate.
member.param: Data-space minimum (left bound) of the X axis
Data-space maximum (right bound) of the X axis
Total drawable width in pixels (must be > 0)
member.returns: Pixel position along X in the range [0, ].

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.Y2Point(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Maps a data-space Y value to the corresponding vertical pixel coordinate.
member.param: Data-space minimum (bottom bound) of the Y axis
Data-space maximum (top bound) of the Y axis
Total drawable height in pixels (must be > 0)
member.returns: Pixel position along Y in the range [0, ], where 0 is the top edge.
member.remarks: Inverts the Y axis (top-left origin) to match typical screen coordinates.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.IsSingularPoint(System.Single)
member.summary: Tests whether a scalar value is singular (not a finite real number).
member.remarks: This is a convenience wrapper for detecting non-finite values.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.ClipPoint(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Clips a value to a half-open range, returning a sentinel just outside if out of bounds.

returns.para: If below the range, returns - 1; if above, returns + 1. This sentinel behavior is useful to mark points as “just outside” the drawable area without losing ordering information.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.GetMin(System.Single[])
member.summary: Returns the minimum finite value in an array, ignoring singular entries.
member.returns: The minimum finite value if present; otherwise when all entries are singular ( or infinities) or the array is empty.
member.remarks: Singular values are filtered using Maths.IsSingular.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.GetMax(System.Single[])
member.summary: Returns the maximum finite value in an array, ignoring singular entries.
member.returns: The maximum finite value if present; otherwise when all entries are singular ( or infinities) or the array is empty.
member.remarks: Singular values are filtered using Maths.IsSingular.

member.name: M:UMapx.Visualization.Points.GetPoints(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates evenly spaced tick marks between and (inclusive).
member.param: Number of intervals to split the range into. The resulting array has length points + 1.
member.returns: An array of size points + 1 containing tick values from to with a uniform step.
member.remarks: The step is rounded to 2 decimal places, which may cause the last tick to deviate slightly from for certain ranges.

member.name: M:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletPack.CQF(System.Single[])
member.summary: Builds the analysis high-pass filter h1 from a real-valued analysis low-pass h0 using the Conjugate-Quadrature-Filter (CQF) relation: h1[n] = (-1)^n * h0[N-1-n]. For a paraunitary (orthonormal) 2-channel bank this must be combined with a properly normalized low-pass (e.g., sum(h0)=√2 and H0(π)=0).

member.name: T:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition
member.summary:
Defines a discrete wavelet decomposition.
For the correct wavelet transform of a signal, it is necessary that its dimension be a power of 2.
More information can be found on the website: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_wavelet_transform

member.name: P:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.Levels
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of transform levels.

member.name: P:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.Wavelet
member.summary: Gets or sets the discrete wavelet.

member.name: M:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.DWT1D(System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Single[])
member.summary: Performs a single-level 1D wavelet analysis (decimation by 2) with periodic boundaries. Writes concatenated coefficients into as [A(0..h-1), D(0..h-1)], where h = bound/2.
member.param: Source samples; only the first values are used
Working length (must be even). Defines h = bound/2
Destination buffer of length receiving A then D
member.remarks: Uses circular (periodic) extension by advancing rotating indices instead of using modulo per tap. If is true, the output bands are scaled by 1/√2 to match orthonormal energy. Complexity: O(bound · (|lp| + |hp|)).

member.name: M:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.IDWT1D(System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Single[])
member.summary: Performs a single-level 1D wavelet synthesis from concatenated bands. Reconstructs a signal of length from a_d = [A(0..h-1), D(0..h-1)], h = bound/2.
member.param: Input buffer holding A followed by D coefficients
Output length (must be even). Defines h = bound/2
member.remarks: Uses odd-phase upsampling (values placed at indices i+1) for both A and D branches to reproduce legacy phasing. Circular (periodic) extension is applied during convolution; indices advance by one per output sample. If is true, the result is scaled by √2 (inverse of analysis scaling). Complexity: O(bound · (|ilp| + |ihp|)).

member.name: M:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.DWT1D(UMapx.Core.Complex32[],System.Int32,UMapx.Core.Complex32[])
member.summary: Performs a single-level 1D wavelet analysis (decimation by 2) with periodic boundaries. Writes concatenated coefficients into as [A(0..h-1), D(0..h-1)], where h = bound/2.
member.param: Source samples; only the first values are used
Working length (must be even). Defines h = bound/2
Destination buffer of length receiving A then D
member.remarks: Uses circular (periodic) extension by advancing rotating indices instead of using modulo per tap. If is true, the output bands are scaled by 1/√2 to match orthonormal energy. Complexity: O(bound · (|lp| + |hp|)).

member.name: M:UMapx.Wavelet.WaveletDecomposition.IDWT1D(UMapx.Core.Complex32[],System.Int32,UMapx.Core.Complex32[])
member.summary: Performs a single-level 1D wavelet synthesis from concatenated bands. Reconstructs a signal of length from a_d = [A(0..h-1), D(0..h-1)], h = bound/2.
member.param: Input buffer holding A followed by D coefficients
Output length (must be even). Defines h = bound/2
member.remarks: Uses odd-phase upsampling (values placed at indices i+1) for both A and D branches to reproduce legacy phasing. Circular (periodic) extension is applied during convolution; indices advance by one per output sample. If is true, the result is scaled by √2 (inverse of analysis scaling). Complexity: O(bound · (|ilp| + |ihp|)).

member.name: T:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform
member.summary:
Defines fast Weyl-Heisenberg transform.
The class represents a computationally efficient implementation of one-dimensional and two-dimensional discrete orthogonal Weyl-Heisenberg transforms. This implementation was designed and developed by Valery Asiryan, Yerevan, Armenia (2025).

member.name: M:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.FWHT(UMapx.Core.Complex32[],UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache)
member.summary:
Forward fast Weyl–Heisenberg transform (2-channel packing, length = 2N).
Input: A ∈ ℂ^N, N = M * L, M is even.
Output: B ∈ ℂ^{2N}, split as: B_main[u] = B[u + 0], u = l*M + k B_half[u] = B[u + N], u = l*M + k
This matches the column-wise “slow” matrix reference G ∈ ℂ^{N×2N} with columns: main: g[i] * exp( j*2π*k/M * (n - M/4) ) half: j*g[j] * exp( j*2π*k/M * (n - M/4) )
Analysis (i.e., G^H A) realized via: - polyphase split over residue n0 (mod M) and FFT_L along r, - frequency-domain correlations with conj(S_hat/T_hat), - carry-phase compensation for the half branch when (n0 + M/2) wraps, - DFT_M over n0 (via forward FFT over n0) + quarter-phase e^{+jπk/2}, - normalization gain = √M / √N = 1 / (2√L).
Notes: Caches C.S_hat, C.T_hat must be built from the SAME orthonormalized window as used by the slow matrix builder, otherwise values will differ by window scaling.
member.returns: B of length 2N: main (0..N-1) and half (N..2N-1) branches

member.name: M:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.IFWHT(UMapx.Core.Complex32[],UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache)
member.summary:
Inverse fast Weyl–Heisenberg transform (2-channel input, length = 2N).
Input: B ∈ ℂ^{2N}, split as: B_main[u] = B[u + 0], u = l*M + k B_half[u] = B[u + N], u = l*M + k
This inverts the forward packing: forward: B_main = P * gain B_half = (-j) Q * gain where gain = √M / √N = 1 / (2√L).
Inverse mapping: P = B_main / gain Q = j * B_half / gain
Then we undo the quarter-phase e^{+jπk/2}, invert the DFT over n₀, apply the adjoint of the frequency-domain correlations, and finally invert the polyphase FFT over r to reconstruct A.
member.param: Input coefficients of length 2N (main first, then half)
Polyphase cache (built for N, M, window)
member.returns: Reconstructed signal A of length N

member.name: T:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache
member.summary:
Defines the polyphase cache for the fast Weyl–Heisenberg transform.
This cache stores precomputed FFTs of the polyphase components of the orthogonalized analysis window. It is used in both forward and backward transforms to avoid recomputing window-related data for each call.
Parameters:
– total signal length
– number of frequency shifts (must be even)
– number of time shifts, L = N / M
– FFTL of the main polyphase branch sn0[r] = g[r*M + n0], dimensions [M, L]
– FFTL of the half-shifted polyphase branch tn0[r] = g[r*M + (n0 + M/2) mod M], dimensions [M, L]
The cache is specific to a given combination of (N, M, window function). If the window changes, the cache must be rebuilt.

member.name: F:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.M
member.summary: Number of frequency shifts (must be even).

member.name: F:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.L
member.summary: Number of time shifts (L = N / M).

member.name: F:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.S_hat
member.summary: FFTL of the main branch polyphase components [M, L].

member.name: F:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.T_hat
member.summary: FFTL of the half-shifted branch polyphase components [M, L].

member.name: M:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,UMapx.Core.Complex32[0:,0:],UMapx.Core.Complex32[0:,0:])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the polyphase cache.
member.param: FFT of the main branch polyphase components
FFT of the half-shifted branch polyphase components

member.name: M:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PolyphaseCache.Build(System.Int32,System.Int32,UMapx.Window.IWindow)
member.summary: Precomputes FFT_L of the polyphase components of the orthogonalized window. These cached arrays S_hat and T_hat are used in both Forward() and Backward() to avoid recomputing window FFTs for every transform call.
member.param: Number of frequency shifts M (must be even)

member.name: M:UMapx.Window.FastWeylHeisenbergTransform.PhasePlusPiOver2(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns the complex phase factor e^{+j * π * k / 2}. This term is 4-periodic in k and takes only four distinct values: 1, +j, −1, −j.
Context: • Quarter-period phase factors appear in WH transforms, DFT twiddle factors, and modulation/demodulation stages. • In the Weyl–Heisenberg transform, this multiplier is used during n₀→k assembly with a positive-exponent DFT to align phases with the matrix reference.
Relationship: PhasePlusPiOver2(k) = conj(PhaseMinusPiOver2(k)).
Mapping (k mod 4): 0 → 1 ( 0°) 1 → +j (+90°) 2 → −1 (180°) 3 → −j (−90°)
member.returns: Complex value of e^{+j * π * k / 2}.
